explanation:
Needed to decide whether the function contains an invariant C-level controlling expression (MISRA rule). Explanation for each symbol:
- MHD_FEATURE_LARGE_FILE: identifies the switch case that contains a conditional (?:) expression; the potential MISRA issue is inside this case.
- HAVE_PREAD64, _WIN32, HAVE_PREAD, HAVE_LSEEK64: these preprocessor macros control which alternative inside the MHD_FEATURE_LARGE_FILE case is compiled. Only some alternatives use the compile-time sizeof(...) comparison (the ternary operator). Knowing which of these macros is defined determines whether the invariant controlling expression is present in the produced C code.
- uint64_t (sizeof): the conditional expression uses sizeof(uint64_t) > sizeof(off_t). sizeof(uint64_t) is a compile-time constant; its value (platform/type definition) is required to determine whether the condition is true or false (i.e. an invariant) and thus whether the controlling expression is invariant.
- off_t (sizeof): same reason as uint64_t: sizeof(off_t) must be known (platform data model / ABI) to evaluate the compile-time comparison and decide if the conditional is an invariant.

With these symbols you can determine (1) whether the ternary controlling expression is present in the compiled function, and (2) whether that controlling expression is a compile-time invariant — which is exactly what the MISRA rule check requires.
